verses.text: That which was from the beginning, that which we have heard, that which we have seen with our very eyes, that which we gazed upon and our hands actually touched—this concerns the Logos of life.
The life was made visible, and we have seen it and testify to it; we announce to you the life of the coming age, which was present with the Father and was made visible to us.

That which we have seen and heard we announce to you as well, so that you too may have a shared life of participation with us. Indeed, this shared life of ours is with the Father and with his Son, Jesus Christ.
And we are writing these things so that our joy may be filled to the brim.
Now this is the message we have heard from him and are reporting to you: God is light, and in him there is no darkness at all.
If we claim to have a shared life of participation with him yet continue to walk in the darkness, we are lying and are not living out the truth.
But if we walk in the light as he himself is in the light, we have a shared life with one another, and the blood of Jesus his Son continually cleanses us from every sin.
If we claim to have no sin-principle within us, we are deceiving ourselves and the truth is not in us.
If we acknowledge our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.
If we claim that we have not actually committed sin, we make him out to be a liar and his Logos has no place in us.

chapters.notes:
**"Logos" (v. 1, 10)**: The Greek term is retained as a loanword. For a first-century reader, *Logos* carried immense weight, signaling the divine rational principle that orders the universe (Hellenistic philosophy) and the creative, personified "Word" of God found in the Hebrew scriptures and Wisdom literature. Translating it simply as "Word" flattens these essential metaphysical and theological connotations.

**"Gazed upon and... touched" (v. 1)**: The author uses increasingly tactile and intensive verbs (*theaomai* and *pselaphao*). While "seen" refers to physical sight, "gazed upon" suggests a deliberate, contemplative observation. "Touched" or "handled" emphasizes the physical reality of the Logos, likely countering early Docetic tendencies that suggested Jesus was a spirit without a physical body.

**"Life of the coming age" (v. 2)**: The Greek *zōēn tēn aiōnion* is traditionally "eternal life." However, in the Jewish and early Christian context, *aiōnios* refers specifically to the *Aeon* (the Age to Come). It is a qualitative term rather than just a quantitative one, referring to the life that belongs to God's future kingdom, now made available in the present.

**"Shared life of participation" (v. 3, 6, 7)**: The Greek *koinōnia* is often translated as "fellowship," but in modern English, "fellowship" has been reduced to social interaction. In the first century, *koinōnia* implied a deep partnership, a sharing of resources, or a common life. The translation "shared life of participation" attempts to capture this sense of a joint-participation in the divine life.

**"Living out the truth" (v. 6)**: The Greek *poioumen tēn alētheian* ("doing the truth") is a Semitic idiom (common in the Septuagint and the Dead Sea Scrolls). It reflects the Hebrew concept of *emet*, where truth is not merely a cognitive category or a set of correct facts, but a way of acting and living in faithfulness to God.

**"Sin-principle" (v. 8)**: The Greek uses the singular *hamartian* (sin) without a definite article. In Johannine thought, this often refers to the internal power or root of sin (the "sin-nature"), whereas the plural *hamartias* in verse 9 refers to the specific acts of wrongdoing.

**"Acknowledge" (v. 9)**: The Greek *homologōmen* literally means "to say the same thing." In a judicial or relational context, it means to agree with God’s assessment of one's actions, rather than just "confessing" in a narrow, ritualistic sense.

verses.text: My dear children, I am writing these things to you so that you do not sin. But if anyone does sin, we have an Advocate in the Father’s presence—Jesus Christ, the Righteous One.
He is the atoning sacrifice that covers our sins, and not only ours, but those of the whole world.
This is how we can be sure that we have come to know him: if we continue to guard his commandments.
The one who says, “I have come to know him,” but does not guard his commandments is a liar, and the truth is not in him.
But whoever guards his word, in this person the love of God has truly been brought to its goal. This is how we know we are in him:
the one who claims to remain in him is obligated to live his life in the same way that he lived.
Beloved, I am not writing a new commandment to you, but an old commandment that you have had from the beginning. This old commandment is the message you have already heard.
On the other hand, I am writing a new commandment to you, which is true in him and in you, because the darkness is passing away and the true light is already shining.
The one who claims to be in the light but hates his brother or sister is in the darkness until now.
The one who loves his brother remains in the light, and there is nothing in him to cause a stumble.
But the one who hates his brother is in the darkness and walks in the darkness; he does not know where he is going, because the darkness has blinded his eyes.
I am writing to you, dear children, because your sins have been forgiven on account of his name.
I am writing to you, fathers, because you have come to know the one who is from the beginning. I am writing to you, young men, because you have conquered the evil one.

I have written to you, children, because you have come to know the Father. I have written to you, fathers, because you have come to know the one who is from the beginning. I have written to you, young men, because you are strong, and the word of God remains in you, and you have conquered the evil one.
Do not love the world or the things in the world. If anyone loves the world, the love of the Father is not in him.
For everything in the world—the cravings of the flesh, the greed of the eyes, and the empty pride of one’s lifestyle—does not come from the Father but from the world.
And the world is passing away, along with its cravings, but the one who does the will of God remains forever.
Children, it is the last hour. Just as you heard that an antichrist is coming, even now many antichrists have appeared. From this we know it is the last hour.

They went out from us, but they did not belong to us; for if they had belonged to us, they would have remained with us. But they went out so that it might be made clear that none of them belong to us.
You, however, have an anointing from the Holy One, and you all have knowledge.
I have not written to you because you do not know the truth, but because you do know it, and because no lie comes from the truth.
Who is the liar if not the one who denies that Jesus is the Christ? This is the antichrist: the one who denies the Father and the Son.
No one who denies the Son has the Father; the one who acknowledges the Son has the Father as well.
As for you, let what you heard from the beginning remain in you. If what you heard from the beginning remains in you, you also will remain in the Son and in the Father.
And this is the promise that he himself promised us: eternal life.
I have written these things to you concerning those who are trying to deceive you.

As for you, the anointing you received from him remains in you, and you have no need for anyone to teach you. Instead, as his anointing teaches you about all things—and it is true and is no lie—and just as it has taught you, remain in him.
And now, dear children, remain in him, so that whenever he is revealed we may have boldness and not shrink away from him in shame at his coming.
If you know that he is righteous, you know that everyone who practices righteousness has been fathered by him.

chapters.notes:
**"Advocate" (v. 1)**: The Greek *paraklēton* refers to someone called to one's side, often in a legal context to provide intercession or defense. While "Helper" or "Comforter" are used in John's Gospel, the context here with "the Father" and "the Righteous One" suggests a forensic or intercessory role in the face of sin.

**"Atoning sacrifice" (v. 2)**: The word *hilasmos* refers to the means by which sins are covered or the divine displeasure is averted. It denotes the removal of the barrier between God and humanity.

**"Guards" (v. 3, 4)**: The verb *tēreō* is often translated as "keep," but it carries a nuance of guarding, watching over, or preserving something of great value.

**"Brought to its goal" (v. 5)**: *Teteleiōtai* (from *teleioō*) means to complete, mature, or bring to an intended end. "Perfected" in modern English often implies moral flawlessness, whereas the Greek implies reaching the intended destination or full expression of love.

**"Brother" (v. 9-11)**: In the context of the Johannine community, *adelphos* ("brother") is a kin-term for a fellow believer. It includes both men and women, but "brother" is retained here to preserve the family-metaphor consistent with "children" and "fathers."

**"Empty pride of one's lifestyle" (v. 16)**: *Alazoneia tou biou* refers to an ostentatious or arrogant display of one's possessions, status, or resources. It is the vaunting of the means of life.

**"Anointing" (v. 20, 27)**: *Chrisma* refers to an application of oil, signifying the reception of the Holy Spirit. It is a wordplay on "Christ" (*Christos*), the "Anointed One."

**"Fathered by him" (v. 29)**: *Gegennētai* refers to the act of procreation or birth. "Born of him" is common, but "fathered" emphasizes the source of life and the paternal relationship established in the preceding verses.

verses.text: See what an extraordinary kind of love the Father has lavished upon us: that we should be called children of God! And that is what we are. The reason the world does not recognize us is that it did not recognize him.
Beloved, we are God’s children right now, and what we will be has not yet been fully disclosed. We know that whenever it is disclosed, we will be like him, because we will see him exactly as he is.
And everyone who has this hope fixed on him purifies themselves, just as he is pure.
Everyone who practices sin also practices lawlessness; indeed, sin is lawlessness.
You know that he was revealed so that he might take away sins, and in him there is no sin.
No one who abides in him continues to sin; no one who continues to sin has seen him or known him.
Little children, let no one lead you astray. The one who practices righteousness is righteous, just as he is righteous.
The one who practices sin is of the devil, because the devil has been sinning from the beginning. The Son of God was revealed for this very purpose: to undo the works of the devil.
No one born of God practices sin, because God’s seed abides in them; they are not able to continue sinning because they have been born of God.
This is how the children of God and the children of the devil are made evident: anyone who does not practice righteousness is not from God, nor is the one who does not love their brother or sister.
For this is the message you have heard from the beginning: that we should love one another.
We must not be like Cain, who belonged to the evil one and slaughtered his brother. And why did he slaughter him? Because his own deeds were evil and his brother’s were righteous.
Do not be surprised, brothers and sisters, if the world hates you.
We know that we have passed out of death and into life because we love our brothers and sisters. The one who does not love remains in death.
Everyone who hates their brother or sister is a murderer, and you know that no murderer has eternal life abiding in them.
This is how we have come to know what love is: that he laid down his own life for us. We, then, are obligated to lay down our lives for our brothers and sisters.
If someone possesses the world’s means of survival and sees a brother or sister in need but closes off their deep compassion from them, how does the love of God abide in them?
Little children, let us not love merely with word or speech, but in action and in truth.
This is how we will know that we belong to the truth and will reassure our hearts in his presence
whenever our hearts condemn us; for God is greater than our hearts, and he knows everything.
Beloved, if our hearts do not condemn us, we have a bold confidence before God;
and whatever we ask, we receive from him, because we keep his commandments and do what is pleasing in his sight.
And this is his commandment: that we put our trust in the name of his Son, Jesus Christ, and love one another, just as he commanded us.
The one who keeps his commandments abides in God, and God abides in them. And we know that he abides in us by this: from the Spirit whom he gave to us.

chapters.notes:
**"Extraordinary kind of love" (v. 1)**: The Greek *potapēn* suggests more than just "how great." It conveys a sense of wonder at something foreign or otherworldly—"from what country or planet?" It emphasizes the unique quality and origin of the Father's love.

**"Lawlessness" (v. 4)**: The term *anomia* is more specific than general wrongdoing. It refers to a state of being "without law" or in active rebellion against God’s order. John equates the essence of sin with this fundamental rejection of divine authority.

**"Continues to sin / Practices sin" (v. 6, 8, 9)**: The Greek uses the present tense (e.g., *hamartanei*, *poiōn tēn hamartian*), which in this context denotes habitual, characteristic action. Translating these as "continues to sin" or "practices sin" distinguishes the believer’s struggle with occasional sin from the unregenerate person’s life-defining orientation toward sin.

**"Undo" (v. 8)**: The verb *lysē* means to "loose," "untie," or "dissolve." While often translated "destroy," "undo" captures the sense of unraveling or dismantling the structures and effects of the devil’s work.

**"God’s seed" (v. 9)**: *Sperma* refers to the principle of divine life implanted in the believer. It is the internal catalyst that makes the life of sin incompatible with the new birth.

**"Slaughtered" (v. 12)**: The verb *esphaxen* is a visceral term often used for the sacrificial cutting of an animal's throat. It suggests a violent, bloody murder, heightening the contrast with the "righteous" deeds of Abel.

**"World’s means of survival" (v. 17)**: The Greek *bion tou kosmou* refers to the material resources necessary for life (food, clothing, money). It is distinct from *zoē* (the principle of life) or *psychē* (the individual life/soul).

**"Deep compassion" (v. 17)**: *Splagchna* literally refers to the "inward parts" or "bowels," which the ancients regarded as the seat of the most intense emotions. "Deep compassion" or "gut-level pity" is the English equivalent.

**"Bold confidence" (v. 21)**: *Parrēsian* refers to freedom of speech or the "unreservedness" one has in the presence of a king or a friend. It is the opposite of the shrinking back caused by a condemning heart.

**"Put our trust in the name" (v. 23)**: The aorist *pisteusōmen* combined with the dative "name" implies a decisive act of allegiance and reliance upon the person and authority of Jesus Christ.

verses.text: Beloved, do not trust every spirit. Instead, put the spirits to the test to see if they originate from God, because many false prophets have gone out into the world.
This is how you recognize the Spirit of God: every spirit that acknowledges Jesus Christ as having come in real human flesh is from God.
But every spirit that does not acknowledge Jesus is not from God. This is the spirit of the Antichrist—you heard that it was coming, and now it is already in the world.
You, dear children, are from God and have overcome those people, because the one who is in you is greater than the one who is in the world.
They belong to the world; therefore, they speak from the world’s perspective, and the world listens to them.
We are from God. Whoever knows God listens to us; whoever is not from God does not listen to us. From this we recognize the spirit of truth and the spirit of deception.
Beloved, let us love one another, because love comes from God, and everyone who loves has been fathered by God and knows God.
The person who does not love has never known God, because God is love.
This is how God’s love was revealed among us: God sent his unique, one-and-only Son into the world so that we might live through him.
This is what love is: not that we loved God, but that he loved us and sent his Son to be the atoning sacrifice that deals with our sins.
Beloved, if God loved us in this way, we also have an obligation to love one another.
No one has ever gazed upon God; yet if we love one another, God remains in us and his love is brought to its full maturity within us.
This is how we know that we remain in him and he in us: he has shared his own Spirit with us.
We have seen for ourselves and now testify that the Father has sent the Son to be the Savior of the world.
Whoever acknowledges that Jesus is the Son of God—God remains in that person and they in God.
We have come to know and trust the love that God has for us. God is love, and the person who remains in love remains in God, and God remains in them.
In this way, love has reached its goal among us, so that we may have bold confidence on the day of judgment, because as he is, so also are we in this world.
There is no fear in love; instead, mature love drives out fear, because fear has to do with the expectation of punishment. The person who lives in fear has not been made mature in love.
We love because he first loved us.
If someone says, "I love God," yet hates his brother or sister, he is a liar. For the person who does not love a brother or sister whom they have seen cannot love God, whom they have not seen.
And we have this commandment from him: the one who loves God must also love his brother and sister.

chapters.notes:
**"Test the spirits" (v. 1)**: The Greek *dokimazete* refers to the process of assaying metals to determine their purity. In this context, it suggests a rigorous evaluation of the source of a prophet's inspiration.

**"In real human flesh" (v. 2)**: The phrasing *en sarki elēlythota* ("having come in flesh") is a specific polemic against Docetism, an early heresy suggesting Jesus only *seemed* to have a physical body. The translation adds "real human" to emphasize the ontological weight the author is placing on the incarnation.

**"Fathered by God" (v. 7)**: The Greek *gegennētai* (from *gennaō*) can mean "born" or "begotten." Given the patriarchal lineage context of the first century, the image is that of God as the source of life, literally "siring" the believer into a new nature.

**"Unique, one-and-only" (v. 9)**: The term *monogenē* is traditionally "only begotten," but in Koine Greek, it emphasizes uniqueness and being "one of a kind." It marks the Son as being in a category of his own.

**"Atoning sacrifice" (v. 10)**: The Greek *hilasmon* is related to the *hilasterion* (the "mercy seat" or "place of atonement" in the LXX). It refers to the means by which a rupture in a relationship is repaired and sins are covered or removed.

**"Brought to its full maturity" (v. 12, 17, 18)**: The root *teleioō* does not mean "perfection" in the sense of being without a flaw (the modern English sense), but rather "reaching its intended end" or "becoming complete/mature." 

**"Bold confidence" (v. 17)**: The Greek *parrēsian* originally referred to the "freedom of speech" a citizen had in a Greek democratic assembly. Here, it denotes the lack of dread or the "boldness" a believer has when standing before God's judgment.

**"Expectation of punishment" (v. 18)**: The word *kolasin* refers to punishment or correction. The text implies that fear exists because of the anticipation of a penalty.

**"Brother and sister" (v. 20-21)**: While the Greek *adelphon* is masculine ("brother"), it was standard usage in early Christian communities to refer to the entire "family" of believers. In a modern context, "brother and sister" accurately reflects the communal and familial scope the author intended.

verses.text: Everyone who believes that Jesus is the Christ has been begotten by God, and everyone who loves the Father who begot him also loves the child begotten by Him.
By this we know that we love the children of God: when we love God and carry out His commandments.
For this is what it means to love God: that we keep His commandments. And His commandments are not a heavy burden,
because everything begotten by God conquers the world. And this is the victory that has conquered the world: our faith.
Who is the one who conquers the world if not the one who believes that Jesus is the Son of God?
This is the one who came through water and blood—Jesus Christ; not by the water only, but by the water and by the blood. And the Spirit is the one testifying, because the Spirit is the truth.
For there are three that testify:
the Spirit, the water, and the blood; and these three are in agreement.
If we accept the testimony of men, the testimony of God is greater; for this is the testimony of God: He has testified concerning His Son.

The one who believes in the Son of God holds this testimony within himself. The one who does not believe God has made Him out to be a liar, because he has not believed in the testimony that God has given concerning His Son.
And this is the testimony: God gave us eternal life, and this life is in His Son.
The one who has the Son has this life; the one who does not have the Son of God does not have this life.
I have written these things to you who believe in the name of the Son of God so that you may know that you have eternal life.
And this is the boldness we have toward Him: that if we ask anything according to His will, He hears us.
And if we know that He hears us in whatever we ask, we know that we possess the requests we have asked of Him.

If anyone sees his brother committing a sin that does not lead to death, he should ask, and God will give life to him—that is, to those whose sin does not lead to death. There is a sin that leads to death; I am not saying that one should pray about that.
All wrongdoing is sin, but there is sin that does not lead to death.
We know that everyone begotten by God does not persist in sinning, but the One begotten by God keeps him safe, and the evil one cannot lay hold of him.
We know that we are from God, while the whole world lies in the power of the evil one.
And we know that the Son of God has come and has given us the capacity to perceive the True One; and we are in the True One, in His Son Jesus Christ. This is the true God and eternal life.
Little children, guard yourselves from idols.

chapters.notes:
**"Begotten" (v. 1, 18)**: The Greek *gennaō* can mean "born" or "begotten." In this context, the author uses the imagery of lineage and parentage to describe the relationship between God, Jesus (the One begotten), and the believer (those begotten). Using "begotten" preserves the internal logic of verse 1, where loving the "one who begot" (the Father) naturally leads to loving the "one begotten" (the child/fellow believer).

**"Heavy burden" (v. 3)**: The Greek *bareiai* means heavy, weighty, or troublesome. In a Jewish context, this alludes to the "yoke" of the law. The author is asserting that the commandments of God, summarized by love, are not an exhausting or crushing weight compared to other religious or worldly obligations.

**"Conquers" (v. 4-5)**: The verb *nikaō* carries a sense of prevailing in a struggle or winning a victory in a contest or battle. "Overcome" is a traditional rendering, but "conquer" better captures the decisive, active triumph intended by the author.

**"Water and blood" (v. 6)**: This is a highly debated phrase. In the historical context of the Johannine community, it likely refutes an early form of Gnosticism (Docetism or Cerinthianism) which claimed Jesus received the "Christ-spirit" at his baptism (water) but that the divine element departed before his suffering (blood). The author insists Jesus is Christ in both his baptism and his sacrificial death.

**"Agreement" (v. 8)**: Literally "the three are into the one" (*eis to hen eisin*). This is an idiom meaning they converge on the same point or speak with one voice.

**"Boldness" (v. 14)**: The Greek *parrhēsia* refers to freedom of speech or the confidence a citizen had to speak plainly before an authority. In the New Testament, it describes the believer’s lack of fear in approaching God.

**"The One begotten by God" (v. 18)**: There is a subtle but vital shift in the Greek. The first phrase "everyone begotten by God" (*pas ho gegennēmenos*) is a perfect participle referring to the believer. The second phrase "the One begotten by God" (*ho gennētheis*) is an aorist participle, which many scholars (and the SBLGNT text) identify as a reference to Jesus Christ, the unique Son who protects the believer. 

**"Capacity to perceive" (v. 20)**: The Greek *dianoia* refers to the faculty of understanding, the mind, or the intellectual capacity to process truth. It is not just "knowledge" (*gnōsis*), but the God-given ability to recognize and understand reality.

**"The True One" (v. 20)**: The Greek *ton alēthinon* refers to God the Father. The verse concludes by identifying this reality—being in the Father and the Son—as the "true God and eternal life."
